title: thoughts-today-messages-strange-special-easter-sunday
story: On this Easter Sunday, The Herald has asked people from all walks of le ndashyoung and old, religious and not ndash to give us their special messages for the country, and the times, we are living in ...ANDREW ROBERTSON, CARE WORKER, ARBROATHldquoThis Easter Sunday Irsquoll be working an am to pm sht at Balhousie Monkbarns care home in Arbroath. You get used to having to work holidays and Irsquom looking forward to making sure our residents have a great time.ldquoWersquove been in lockdown for several weeks. A lot of the residents are confused about why they canrsquot see their relatives, but the majority of them are coping well. Itrsquos our job to keep their minds active and make sure their days are as close to normal as possible. Wersquore planning an Easter egg hunt inside the care home, there will probably be dominoes and other games, and there will be Skyping with relatives. The kindness our local community has been amazing. Wersquove had a donation of Easter eggs from our local Home Bargains store.ldquoMy partner and two kids will be doing an Easter egg hunt in our garden but without our nephews and nieces this year. Irsquom going to miss the usual gathering of relatives but Irsquoll be with my other family. We always say we treat our residents like family, but itrsquos more important right now than ever.Andrew Robertson is a Senior Care Assistant at Balhousie Monkbarns care home in Arbroath.ANNIE SCOTT, SCHOOL-LEAVER, GLASGOW"The class of  had high hopes for this year. I remember the shock that rippled round the school when its closure was announced: our last few weeks of school would be stripped away with no graduation, no prom, and no s holidays. All the things we believed, in a sense, were owed to us for surviving six years of secondary education. But it is not only our present that has been compromised: Many uni placeshang in the balance and itrsquos hard not to spend all day sleeping to escape all the uncertainty."This is a challenging time for us all, and while therersquos no denying that our health care heroes are bearing the brunt of this pandemic, teenagers have proven their resilience, picking themselves up, dusting themselves off and still making the house party by pm. I have new-found admiration for my generation for realising that their stolen milestones are not the end of the world."So I say,  babies, donrsquot let this get you down! Take it easy and remember the good times will roll on before you know."EMMA STEWART, SELF-ISOLATING, DENNY"Before this, I was living alone. But I was okay, because I was out every day, for five, six hours. But now Irsquom forced to stay in for  weeks, honest to God, itrsquos hard to accept. People talk about FaceTime. I donrsquot have a computer. I lost a lot of motivation. I was really getting down. It took the wind out of my sails. It feels like being in prison. I hate being restricted. I like going out, getting on a bus and going wherever. But I canrsquot do that."Irsquove got damage to my lungs, so I have to stay in. You get a letter about power of attorney and resuscitation and that did freak me out. I couldnrsquot come to terms with the fact that ndash although I was  ndash I was vulnerable. Irsquove just got to accept it. Irsquom reading, Irsquom doing my crosswords. Irsquom watching some television. Irsquom tidying up drawers."But Irsquom looking forward to getting let free and doing what I want to do, getting a bus, going away somewhere, walking round the shops, doing anything as long as Irsquom out."REBECCA MCEWEN, FARMER, STIRLINGSHIRE"Things feel dferent but also the same because in April and early May we are usually on social lockdown here at Arnprior Farm due to lambing. The main dference this year is we have no veterinary students to help out. The team this year is our family ndash myself, my husband Duncan, my father-in-law, my mother-in-law, my three children ndash and two of our workers. We lamb , sheep inside, so its a   operation."With the schools closed, the kids are around all the time. My house is like a bomb site and wersquore eating stew after stew. I stick it on to cook in the morning and hope itrsquos not burnt when we arrive home at pm. Last year we built a swimming pool and glamping pods on the farm where visitors can stay. Those are currently closed. We have also had to cancel our ticketed lambing experience but are hoping to welcome people later in the summer."My message would be stay at home this Easter. Lockdown isnrsquot forever. It is a small sacrice and one we can all make to help saves lives."MALIN WOLLBERG, FOOD VOLUNTEER, EDINBURGH"Im from Sweden and volunteered in Calais for a year with Refugee Community Kitchen before moving to Edinburgh to found Nourishing Change with my partner Nick Cullen and friends Dave Matthews, Joe Simpson and Bruno Santos. We use the skills we gained in Calais to support local projects that tackle food insecurity. At the moment, a typical day for me involves coordinating volunteers, drivers, and chefs. I will map out which meals need to go where for the next day, heading to our storage and distribution hub to help with stock management and logistics. In the evening I tend to work on ways to locate and sustainably support people in need of food."Last week alone ndash as a partner organisation in the Edinburgh Food for Good Coalition ndash we made more than , meals and rely on crowdfunding to support the operation."My message would be one of solidarity: to look after yourselves and each other. Together, communities have the strength to weather this storm."LEE CRAIGIE, CARGO BIKE DELIVERY RIDER, EDINBURGH"My usual job is as Active Nation Commissioner for Scotland where I work strategically to encourage people to walk, run or cycle to work school instead of drive so that we might all be healthier and more environmentally aware. During this crisis, it feels important to act rather than just talk and so I am combining my love of bike riding with food deliveries. My partner and I have an Omniumthat can carry loads of up kg."Sustrans Cargo Bike Library have lent us an additional one and together we spend the afternoons delivering produce around for a zero-waste social enterprise, The Eco Larder. In the evening, we pick up surplus food from generous supermarkets and take it to homeless hostels so that organisations like Streetwork can continue to keep others safe and healthy."Riding around the streets it feels like wersquove all gone back to a time there were less cars so more people rode bikes and walked places, when we shopped locally, buying only what we need and had time for our family and neighbours. We canrsquot control things, but we can make the most of them."ANGIE CAMERON, THERAPIST, EDINBURGH"Irsquove been holding mindful meditation sessions, which I used to do in person, on Zoom call. There are people doing it who wouldnrsquot always do mindful meditation, but I think people are being a bit more open-minded. After the sessions, people have got back to me saying, Irsquom so much calmer. Itrsquos really helped me."Irsquom also seeing in the psychotherapy that I do that whatrsquos happening is bringing up some past trauma around loss and grief for people, which maybe will make them consider their own lives. Itrsquos allowing people to take stock. Therersquos not one person that Irsquove spoken to thatrsquos not grateful for something right now. It doesnrsquot matter whether itrsquos spending time with their kids or not having the pressure. There are the negative sides. Wersquore all more skint ndash some more so than others. And, of course, therersquos so much sadness. Butthis could open us up to some gratefulness that would normally pass us by, then isnrsquot that beautul "RT REV COLIN SINCLAIR, MODERATOR OF THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE CHURCH OF SCOTLAND"There are many things we associate with Easter. The days are getting longer, buds and blossom are appearing on the trees and we see clumps of daffodils appearing but it doesnrsquot feel like Easter because normal le is on hold. Churches are closed, families are in lockdown and there will be no gatherings, picnics or Easter egg hunts."Yet perhaps we have a chance of understanding Easter in a new way. For the followers of Jesus, the start of the first Easter Sunday was not a special day. He was gone and their dreams, hopes and vision for the future died. So they, like us, that first Easter had no gatherings for worship and the disciples were in lockdown. But after the resurrection death was defeated, hope was reborn and that Friday was rebadged Good Friday. It seems to me that is a pretty good reason for us to celebrate Easter this year. Christ is risen ndash He is risen indeed."Hallelujah!"SCOTLANDrsquoS CATHOLIC BISHOPS"The pandemic is afflicting the whole world and we pray for all those who have caught the virus, their loved ones and those caring for them. Our lives are greatly restricted and on Easter Sunday, the holiest day of the Christian calendar, we will not be able to go to church. It is hard but as Christians we know that the risen Lord is our hope. His suffering death and resurrection give us hope that we will recover, that le will get better and that our nation will feel the peace and love of the risen Christ."We also have hope in the ingenuity and the generosity of humanity. Though many uncertainties lie ahead, our hope and our determination to recover the lives we once lived is strong. We especially give thanks for the commitment and compassion of our medical professionals and we pray that all their decisions will respect the lives of the most vulnerable, entrusted to their care. We pray too for the researchers working to develop a vaccine and for our political leaders who must make dficult decisions. May God bless you all and our world this Easter."Bishop Hugh Gilbert, Bishop John Keenan, Bishop Brian McGee, Archbishop Philip Tartaglia, Archbishop Leo Cushley, Bishop Joseph Toal, Bishop William Nolan, Bishop Stephen Robson

title: vicky-allan-feeling-hope-even-dark-time
story: Since this whole crisis started, Irsquove kept wondering whether Irsquom ready yet to talk, or even think, about hope. In those first weeks, it seemed all too early. Some out there were identying silver linings, like the fake news that there were dolphins in the canals of Venice, or that ndash and this was true ndash pollution had almost melted away over China, or even that we could hear the birdsong better. But it felt to me we were too early in the grief cycle of denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. Therersquos a hope that is about not accepting what has happened, or its true gravity. I wanted to resist that  hope.Still, itrsquos Easter and now Irsquom listening to the blackbirds singing ndash in the dead of night ndash and thinking about hope. For in the tiny moments when I can step back from my fear for myself and loved ones, hope is what I find myself looking for. Itrsquos all too easy to gaze out and see only the story that ends badly, the oncoming economic depression in which the poor are made poorer and the rich hold on to their wealth and health, or the segueing of disasters, one into another, in which our children find themselves lurching from pandemic to climate crisis. Many of us are finding that our thoughts are in a very black place. The nights can be long and wakeful.So we do need to foster hope ndash and thatrsquos an active process. You have to work at it. You have to plant seeds. You have to water them. Hope doesnrsquot really last without doing anything. It doesnrsquot survive long as just an idea in your head. Itrsquos all about finding those grains of something you can work with. And they exist ndash itrsquos just they seem more dficult to access, more virtual, in an era when we are being told to stay at home. Even the reaching out wersquore doing across the internet is a start. Even our clapping for the NHS provokes hope that we can come together and create a society in which our carers are valued.Many people are already looking for new roles ndash what they can do, not only to help others now, but perhaps as part of some human movement towards creating a better society, somewhere at the almost unimaginable end of all this. Wersquove signed up for things. Wersquove helped neighbours out. Wersquove felt inadequate, and worried we have nothing to offer. Wersquore still trying to work out , and how, the things we used to value and fight for matter in this new universe. Many of them still do. What we always used to hope for ndash a fairer world, a new relationship with the environment, an end to homelessness ndash seems all the more important now, evenour immediate concern is the virus threat. As Rebecca Solnit wrote this week: ldquoOne of our main tasks now ndash especially those of us who are not sick, are not frontline workers, and are not dealing with other economic or housing dficulties ndash is to understand this moment, what it might require of us, and what it might make possible.These problems ndash how to reinvent our economic system, how to change our physical impact on the planet or how to rejuvenate mental health ndash are issues people have been proposing solutions to for some time. There are blackbirds out there that have almost been waiting for this moment to arise. It may seem crazy to hope that this crisis could be what propels these ideas into action, but one thing about the dramatic change we are experiencing is that it does make other change feel more possible. We now see, for instance, that we donrsquot have to constantly travel around trailing emissions. People can stop flying. Homeless people can be put into empty Airbnb flats. The British state can reinvent itself at startling speed. The virus has brought many terrying changes with it ndash but some of the changes it has brought are in themselves, hope. Irsquoll water that.TWITCHYcoronavirus rulesThe curtains are twitching. The smartphones are twitching too, every time someone sees someone out in the park, not quite keeping the two-metre rule, even though they may be a group that lived crammed together in a small flat with zero outdoor space. We have become, almost overnight, a nation of twitchers and shamers. Thatrsquos understandable.But letrsquos cut each other some slack. Letrsquos not take this whole thing a twitch too far.

title: memories-different-type-lockdown-10-years
story: Or so we thought. The Eyjafjallajokull volcano in Iceland had other ideas. Three days after we flew out, airspace over much of northern Europe closed due to the thick ash cloud clogging the skies. It would remain that way for around a week.By the time it reopened, tens of thousands of planes, crew and passengers were in the wrong place. Even as aircraft began flying again, there was a huge backlog. When I spoke to the airline call centre, I was told the first available flight home would be May  ndash some  days later.So, what to do on an extended honeymoon . My phone pinged with envious messages from friends. Stories were swapped with fellow stranded travellers. I even wrote a column for this newspaper.: Susan Swarbrick: Nature reminds us that this lockdown limbo wont last foreverHeres the thing, though. Enforced paradise is a novelty that can quickly wear off. Island fever set in. Hours were whiled away watching the lizards dance nimble-footed across the walls or gazing hypnotised at the whirring ceiling fan.The news channels played on a loop in the background. I swallowed down my envy when those lucky enough to get a seat on a plane cheerily waved for the cameras in airport arrival halls.Partly out of necessity, partly from boredom, I washed a pile of knickers and my husbands underpants in the bathroom sink. I mainlined so many Adam Sandler films on pay-per-view that seeing him now brings me out in a rash .It was a dferent type of lockdown. Then, I couldnt wait to get off and moving. Now, Im grateful for the opportunity to be still.In , I didnt jolt wake at am, my brain racing to escape a fug of existential dread. I wasnt worrying about loved ones. Nor fighting back tears as I stood on my front step, clapping for key workers ndash those who heroically staff our hospitals, care homes, supermarkets and more ndash every Thursday at pm.: Susan Swarbrick: Nature reminds us that this lockdown limbo wont last foreverJust like  years ago, theres barely a plane in the sky over Scotland. When I looked at the Flightradar app the other night, there was only one: an air ambulance taking off from Aberdeen.As Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz astutely said, theres no place like home. Which is why we should stay there. All of our lives depend on it.Shops across Scotland are closing. Newspaper sales are falling. But weve chosen to keep our coverage of the coronavirus crisis free because its so important for the people of Scotland to stay informed during this dficult time.However, producing The Heralds unrivalled analysis, insight and opinion on a daily basis still costs money, and we need your support to sustain our trusted, quality journalism.To help us get through this, were asking readers to take a digital subscription to The Herald. You can sign up now for just pound for two months.If you choose to sign up, well offer a faster loading, advert-light experience ndash and deliver a digital version of the print product to your device every day. Click here to help The Herald: https:www.heraldscotland subscribe  Thank you, and stay safe.

title: revealed-320-000-scots-firms-no-insurance-covid
story: According to the Association of British Insurers , just % of firms across the country have business interruption insurance which covers pandemics and, of these, even fewer will have policies which include any "notiable disease".Businesses which do have specic disease cover are also struggling to claim funds, with politicians now calling for insurers to step up and stop ldquopassing the buck to avoid paying out those who believe they are entitled to a claim.Analysis of official Labour Market Statistics, conducted by The Herald on Sunday, shows at least , registered firms in Scotland will have closed completely or been drastically affected by the pandemic, including all shops which sell non-food items, construction sites, hairdressers, cinemas, pubs, restaurants and sports clubs.This does not include non-registeredfirms, which make up almost half of Scotlands businesses, so the true figure it likely to be far higher.:Poverty, lockdown or missed Covid cases - what is really driving the mystery surge in Scottish deaths Aside from those ordered to close or cease operations by the Government, many of the countrys , companies will have lost staff due to illness, or furlough, while logistics are making it impossible for some manufacturing firms to deliver their products.MPs from across the country say they have been inundated with messages from mainly small companies who have been denied payments by their insurers, and who cannot afford to take them to court to challenge their decisions.Anecdotally, they say, some firms have been told the Covid- virus is not SARS and, as their policy is only valid for SARS, they could not claim. In another case, a dferent business was told the virus was SARS, but their policy excluded SARS and so they would not receive a payout either.These discrepancies have prompted outrage from politicians, with several SNP members now writing to the head of the ABI, Huw Evans, demanding urgent action.Case study:Business owner devastated by art school fire faces second insurance fight over Covid-Alyn Smith, SNP MP for Stirling, and John Nicolson, MP for Ochil and South Perthshire, are among those who wrote to Edwards this week explaining that they are ldquobeing contacted daily about the issue.Their letter states: ldquoThese businesses cannot operate, as per UK and Scottish Government instruction, and as a result have no income stream ... They remain extremely troubled by the potential closure of their business as a result of the stance taken by insurers.Smith said: ldquoI raised the conduct of insurance companies in parliament weeks ago, and since, sadly, like all my colleagues have had dozens of constituents getting in touch about insurance companies either trying to get out of their obligations or being posted missing when theyrsquore most needed.ldquoThe insurance industry is in trouble, I get it, the scale of the losses over this pandemic are dwarfing anything the insurance or global reinsurance market have ever seen.ldquoI do think there is a need for the state to stand behind some or all of the policies to ensure people have certainty and am glad our Treasury spokesperson Alison Thewlis has been so active in pressing this case.ldquoBut it is simply not good enough. Businesses have taken precautions in good faith and are finding their expensive policies to be worthless. We need to see the UK lose the laissez faire attitude and get in about these companies.Dr Liz Cameron, chief executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said that the SCC was aware of businesses facing problems with their insurers, adding: ldquoEarlier this year, the Scottish Government and UK Government formally declared that coronavirus was a lsquonotiable diseasersquo. This would normally help companies seek compensation through their insurance policies in the event of any cancellations they may have to make as a result of the spread of the virus.: Fears grow over Covid- debt crisisldquoWe urge businesses to engage directly with their insurer or broker to discuss and confirm the type of cover that they have purchased and whether or not it covers coronavirus. This pandemic is an unparalleled crisis in modern times and we urge insurers to be as collaborative and supportive as possible.rsquorsquoHowever, the ABI says that, while insurers are preparing to pay out up to poundbn in total to cover travel, retail and entertainment industries, they simply cannot be responsible for funding everyone who has lost out during the pandemicthey do not have policies which cover them.The body is also calling for talks with the Government on how to make pandemic cover more affordable for all firms, in case such an unprecedented situation arises in the future.An ABI spokesman said: ldquoInsurers understand that this is a very worrying and uncertain time for all businesses. Some businesses may have bought pandemic insurance that will pay out for Covid- but most will have not.ldquoIt is expected that coronavirus-related claims will be well in excess of pound billion in the UK spread over at least a dozen dferent types of insurance, including cover for business.ldquoNo country in the world is able to offer widespread pandemic insurance. If insurers paid out for cover that wasnrsquot included in contracts it would be a shortcut to their insolvency. For pandemic insurance to be more widespread, there needs to be some form of government support. Once we are through this we need a debate about how this can best be achieved.:Coronavirus: A timeline showing the UK regions with the highest number of casesWatchdogs the Financial Conduct Authority and the Financial Ombudsman Service said they were aware of the problems affecting firms, with the FCA confirming they had already started receiving complaints about insurers failing to pay out.

title: rosemary-gorings-country-life-eery-silence-lambs
story: Had anyone been so sneaky, it would have been a bad move. The place was an Aladdinrsquos cave of implements for cutting, sawing, pounding, impaling. If you owned a Texas ranch and had a yearning to renew the fences, everything yoursquod need is here. So tooyou had to exterminate rats or mice, wasps, beetles, or any other pest that was getting in your way. There was a corner devoted to horses, with enough combs, brushes and hoof-picks to tart them up for Ascot. And there were elixirs and ointments and dips not only for horses but for sheep, pigs and cattle.The store is well placed, beside an auction market. Hundreds of metal corrals encircle the trading hub of this historic mart, the first of its kind in Scotland. It was opened in  by a butcher whose we realised he could do better for himself, and persuaded him to go into the auctioning business.Early in the morning, several times a week, farmers pass our cottage, heading for the mart with lorries and trailers packed with cattle and sheep. A short while later they rattle back home empty. In the present lock-down they are almost the only traffic going by, and I picture all us villagers lting our heads from whatever wersquore doing to watch. Tractors are even more exciting. One went past four times in each direction the other Sunday ndash just turning my head made me feel wiped out.At this time of year, tractors are busy harrowing and fertilising, but the most important activity is lambing. Irsquove never understood why, at Easter, we celebrate with chocolate rabbits when it is newly arrived lambs we should be thinking of. Everywhere you look there are picture-book hillsides of grazing ewes, eating asat an all-day buffet, while their infants dance like popcorn all over the place.By March, lambing season is in full swing, and gravelly bleating is, for me, the sound of spring. As daffodils splash verges and woods with colour, lambs cavort with no thought for tomorrow . The other day, on my way home from a hardware store ndash we needed to repair our wood-burning stove ndash we passed a field whose corner had been fenced off to create a maternity ward. The midwersquos caravan was parked among them, presumably making the midnight sht a little less arduous. Two lambs, sitting as close as eggs in a box, stared at me with beady black eyes, so motionless they appeared not even to blink. At a few days old, they were brilliant white, asstraight out of the washing machine. Their mother, in contrast, was a mess. Her filthy fleece hung off her in shreds, like a catwalk model swaggering down the podium, her woolly cape worn so low off the shoulder it almost trips her up.For any ewe about to go into labour, seeing a new mother in such a ragged state can do nothing for their nerves. Nature is meant to take its course easily in the sheep pen, with none of the coaxing, hand-holding or pain relief humans generally need. And when it comes to the farmyard, most of the time thatrsquos how it works. But as anyone who read James Herriot as a youngster knows, things can quickly go wrong. When they do, it iniably requires middle-of-the-night trips to snow-bound barns, and armpit- gloves.Sheep, a vet once told me, are always finding new ways of dying. Whether during pregnancy and birth, or out on the summer hills, their capacity to self-destruct is impressive. I spare you the details over your quailsrsquo eggs and kedgeree. I spent a lot of time, once, talking to hill sheep farmers, shepherds and vets for a book I was writing. Studying a veterinary textbook on ruminants and their ailments, and the photos in particular, was the most effective diet I ever went on.It made me realise how stoical these creatures are, and how much we take them for granted. With our streets empty and silent, and the knowledge of a highly contagious disease on the loose, these eery times are reminiscent of the dreadful Foot and Mouth outbreak in . Back then, throughout East Lothian where I lived, and in Dumfries and Galloway, where friends were farmers, there was a deathly hush in the countryside. The sight of empty green slopes, where there should be flocks and herds, was a definition of abnormal. As was driving through disinfectant at the gates of every farm. Worst of all were Hieronymus Bosch landscapes of smoking pyres. To blot out the sight and smell, farmers closed windows and curtains.Until that calamity I had never fully appreciated how big a part farm animals play in my understanding and enjoyment of the country. Now that it is us who are under threat, the tables are turned. But for all the bucolic charm of seeing lambsrsquo tails whirling like windmills as they suckle, this season is becoming a headache for farmers. Until Covid-, their main worry was the impact Brexit would have on trade deals and the price of home-reared meat. All that seems far off right now. With some abattoirs and most international borders closing, the farm calendar of breeding, rearing and slaughtering is at grave risk of disruption in the coming months. Among the lessons this crisis might teach us is the value of locally grown produce, and the necessity of being as self-sufficient a country as possible.While we get through this unnerving situation, those of us who live within sight and sound of frolicking lambs, or who follow media-savvy shepherds online, are grateful. The natural order of things is carrying on all around, just waiting for our .

story: TAKEN in the round, all things considered, including the moral and spiritual aspects, and trying to remember onersquos wider social responsibilities, I believe that, on the whole, I am in favour of being given money for nothing.Ergo, a Universal Basic Incomegets my vote. In the wake of the coronavirus, the Spanish Government has declared an aim of rolling out just such a thing ndash and not just for a wee laugh. It wants UBI to become something ldquothat stays forever, that becomes a structural instrument, a permanent instrument.Thatrsquos right ambitious. Most of us look at UBI and think: "Yoursquore having a laugh. How could that possibly work " In cruel and harsh countries like Britain, furthermore, the idea of giving people money for nothing induces bouts of violent vomiting in the boardrooms and executive lounges of our puritanicalbourgeoisie.However, proponents of UBI argue that, counter-intuitive though it seems, by the time you cut out the bureaucracy surrounding welfare means-testing, the thing might even make economic sense.They also point to studies purporting to show that folk will still want to work rather than receive money for nothing, and that would particularly be the case in Britain where we all know the sum would be so low that you could hardly buy a tin of corned beef and a bottle of vintage Buckfast with it.The question is: would there be work to go to  The effect of coronavirus on the economy could be catastrophic but, more than that, wersquore said to be approaching a time when robots will put millions out of work.And it wonrsquot just be the poorer classes affected by that. Middle-class professions could also suffer. Believe me, when they start putting the lawyers out of work, therersquoll be lawless riots on the streets, with people in rugby tops and chinos demanding enough UBI to pay the au pair and attend the opera or even a football match.You must factor in too that, after the measures taken during the coronavirus, no one has much time any more for free market, kill-the-weak economics.The seething but hitherto dormant rage about a British economy that in normal times features useless articles ldquoearning more in a minute than valuable workers earn in a decade might boil over, with demands for change fuelled by the perception that itrsquos largely been the low-paid whorsquove been heroes in the frontline during the battle against coronavirus.So, could we be on the brink of a -type radical change in society towards socialism when this wretched war is over  Itrsquoll dependwe come out of social isolation hellip and revert to our socially atomised lives.At the moment, wersquore all in this together. Afterwards, wersquoll probably go our separate ways again, ided by class, gender and philosophy. But, in the meantime, some money would certainly come in handy. We might even like the country that gave us it and want to pay it back in some way.Animal magicLIKE most decent ratepayers, Irsquom appalled by the idea of being reincarnated. The thought of having to go through this ongoing farce again, perhaps even in the form of a dopey animal or witless insect, is just too awful to contemplate.However,it was forced upon us by the celestial authorities in the Ministry of Reincarnation and Endless Torment, then perhaps there would be worse lots than being a panda. My soul might easily migrate to that form.Theyrsquore shy like me and donrsquot like fancy food. Just give me some bamboo in broon sauce, preferably with a large handful of oven chips , and Irsquod be fine. But I think that,Irsquom reincarnated as a panda, it had best be done in the wild.As a shy person, I canrsquot bear people gawping at me at the best of times, and would particularly deplore it when trying to copulate. Surely, it would put you off a bit Well, thatrsquos been the lot of pandas in zoos for some time. And the humans wonder why theyrsquore not providing offspring. Drsquouh.However, now that zoos have shut to gawpers, reports suggest that pandas have been loosening up a little and getting to know each other in the biblical sense.Ying Yingand Le Le , of Ocean Park zoo in Hong Kong, for example, have reportedly indulged in lewd and libidinous behaviour, leading to hopes that, after  years, a cub might be imminent.But imaginethe zoo is reopened to the public again when the little fellow is due to hatch. A brief look at the gawping humans, and the wee bairn will wail: ldquoAw naw. I told them I didnrsquot want to come back as a panda. I wanted to come back as a Rab.Five things we learned this week Archaeologists have developed a new method of dating objects, using the bits of food left on dirty dishes. Clarty Neolithic pots dug up in Shoreditch, east London, were found to date from BC, or BD . A shock TV documentary investigating Waitrose found that a dog food on sale in its stores featured ingredients including wild boar, apple, parsnip and seaweed. If yoursquore stocking up on tins at the moment, you might want to give that one a try. Yummy. Scotland has been named home to the worldrsquos earliest surviving record of the F-word. A BBC documentary unearthed the expletive in a vituperative poem from  called The Flyting of Dumbar and Kennedie. Sounds like a right pile of flyte. Food historian Glyn Hughes caused controversy after claiming pasties had been around for thousands of years before Cornwall cornered the market. Cornish folk reacted with outrage, saying the claims were flaky and promising to make Glyn eat his words. Baking banana bread, growing tomatoes, and fancying Chancellor Rishi Sunak are classic indicators of middle-class lockdown behaviour, according to Scottish writer Flic Everett. Other suggestions on Twitter included ldquosushi on the balcony after a spot of pulse yoga. Yikes!

title: coronavirus-scotland-nutrition-tips-eat-drink-lockdown
story: Nutritionist Sarah Ormerod has been affected by restrictions during lockdown which means she is unable to meet clients face-to-face. However, she has seen enquiries increase during this time and has been running a virtual service.She said: ldquoOver the past few weeks I have been offering nutrition consultations to people who feel they need a little extra support as they adapt to these new circumstances. While these are complimentary, there is also an option to make a voluntary donation to the National Emergencies Trust Coronavirus Appeal. All funds raised will be distributed to charities supporting those most affected by the pandemic."Hopefully, I can provide some inspiration on how to use this testing time positively, stay resilient, look after our health and that of our loved ones.Here are her top tips:Eat for your immune system and mood: Opt for a diet rich in colourful fruit and vegetables . They are packed with vitamins, minerals and antioxidants all contributing to a healthy immune . These may be harder to get hold of right now, so also consider frozen or tinned options, stewed fruit to make it last for longer and soaking dried fruit when fresh isnrsquot available.When writing your shopping list, here is a run-down of some nutrients to pay particular attention to:# Vitamin C, which can be found in citrus fruits , kiwis, strawberries, broccoli, sprouts, red and green peppers and berries . It may enhance the effectiveness of our immune systemrsquos first line of defence and effectiveness of the immune cells responsible for eliminating free radicals.# Vitamin A, found in orange and yellow fruit, and vegetables such as butternut squash, carrots and sweet potatoes as well as broccoli, spinach and dark green leafy veg. It helps keep the bodyrsquos first line of defence healthy by regulating something called secretory IgA.Manage stress: Stressful situations stimulate cortisol, the stress hormone, which when chronically raised can impact on immune . Build some calming activities into your day ndash conscious breathing exercises, yoga, listening to calming music, drawing, breathing in some fresh airyou can and carving out time to speak to loved ones. Find what works for you and make it a priority.Increasing your intake of foods rich in magnesium and B vitamins such as green leafy veg , nuts and seeds, crucerous veg , legumes and seafood may also help to balance the nervous system.Find and follow a routine: Our schedules usually enforced by external factors ndash the school run, getting out to work, exercise classes ndash are now in disarray. Striking a new routine, keeping a regular sleep wake cycle, setting "working hours", time for exercise and taking breaks, will give you a sense of normality. Make dferent plans for the weekend to distinguish between the working week and your down time.Move every day: Exercise is not only proven to support physical and mental wellbeing, but the daily endorphins will give you a much-needed lt. If you can get outside, use your "daily allowance" to soak up some vitamin D, fresh air and exposure to nature. If you canrsquot leave the house for a run, walk or cycle, try some body weight exercises ndash squats, lunges, planks, press-ups, some yoga or interval training. There are loads of online resources available to follow at home.Prioritise sleep: Strong evidence exists that sleep enhances immune defence and helps healing. When we donrsquot get enough our infection-fighting antibodies and immune cells are compromised. Aim for seven to eight hours a night, keep a regular sleep wake cycle with the aim of being asleep by pm as the immune system is believed to recharge between pm and am. Moderate your screen time each day, particularly late in the evening when yoursquore winding down for bed.And, lastly ...Remember the principle of impermanence: Nothing lasts, everything passes. In the meantime, letrsquos use this time to do the best we can with what we have.Sarah Ormerod, founder of Thryve Nutrition, is a nutritional therapistspecialising in nutrition for endurance sport. "Pay what you feel" consultations can be booked via her website www.thryvenutrition

title: ron-mckays-diary-memories-mean-spirits-never-forgetting
story: Rummaging through a drawer in the kitchen the other day, bored, looking for I know not what, I came across a rather careworn Polaroid photograph dating back more years than I want to recall. I donrsquot know why it was filed among discarded gts from Christmas crackers, bent cutlery and a corkscrew , but it was. When I rubbed away on the surface it revealed me with my arm round the legendary photographer Harry Benson. It was taken by his we Gigi at the Old Course in Troon, where Harry was brought up and where he was back visiting.The word legend is carelessly bandied about, but in this case it applies in neon. Harry was a well-known snapper when he first travelled to the USA with The Beatles in , during their first barnstorming tour of the country, and he decided to stay. Well, the money was better for a start. His pictures ndash and you will have seen them ndash have appeared in Le, Vanity Fair and The New Yorker. Hersquos also taken more than  cover shots for People magazine and appeared in countless other publications.Harry chronicled some of the most important moments in modern history. He has photographed every US president from Eisenhower to Trump, the Queen several times, was feet away from Bobby Kennedy the night he was assassinated ndash ldquoI kept telling myself lsquothis is for history, pull yourself together, fail tomorrow, not todayrsquo ndash and he was in the room with Richard Nixon when he resigned. He witnessed the Berlin Wall being built and taken down, and was on civil rights marches with Martin Luther King Jr. He has history coursing through his veins.He also took some stunning and shocking shots of Glasgow, where he was born. Andyou look at his website yoursquore greeted with a large black-and-white picture of Richard Burton giving mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to Elizabeth Taylor.As we knocked around Troon, Harry showed me one shot he had taken of a major film star which Vanity Fair had passed on because it revealed a track of cocaine from the actorrsquos left nostril. Harry is also a national treasure ndash hersquos still living in New York and on the go at . Legends never die.Yeah, yeah, yeahHarry Benson was yet to photograph them, but it was on this day in  that the launch of what was shortly to become a worldwide and unprecedented musical phenomenon occurred ndash The Beatles released their first single, Please, Please Me.Coronavirus churlTramping the streets on my permitted walk during the week I noticed a note under a car windscreenand, being a naturally nosy chap, I took a look.A few hours later the ldquoguilty party responded on Facebook .Enough said.Cleaning upIn this time of pestilence and tribulation you can become obsessed with the trivial, although for me that also pre-dates the pandemic. The live-in daughter, the lawyer, who has never scrubbed a sink or washed a floor in her le, points me to someone called Mrs Hinch who is something called an influencer, because she has three million followers on Instagram who apparently take her advice about which product to scour their lavvie with.Hinch, who is a -something Essex mother, has apparently made a million or more posting videos of her cleaning rituals. Personally Irsquod rather watch paint dry than her spraying her shower and getting stuck in with the rubber gloves. She holds up the cleaner pack to camera before getting busy and apparently each posting earns her around poundk from the manufacturer, and then next day Home Bargains is cleaned out of it by the YouTube generation.Itrsquos cheap advertising for the company, I suppose, and good for Mrs Hinch, who apparently used to suffer with severe anxiety ndash cleaning became her coping mechanism. Yoursquod think she might have some compulsive disordershe wasnrsquot laughing into her Marigolds all the way to the bank.Fake news Why has Donald Trump so vigorously promoted hydroxychloroquine as a cure for Covid- when therersquos not, as yet, a scintilla of scientic evidence that it works  Itrsquos an anti-malaria drug which also can have severe side-effects, ranging from nausea and hair loss to blindness and cardiac arrest, and, since Trump championed it, speculators have been stockpiling. Itrsquos manufactured by Sanofi, the French pharmaceutical company, and marketed as Plaquenil.Itrsquos inconceivable that the President would champion it because three family trusts have investments in a mutual fund whose largest holding is in Sanofi stock. Isnrsquot it The poundk questionTwo of my kids have been furloughed from their jobs, on % of their pay. The UK Parliament is also effectively furloughed but MPs are still on their poundk pay. Just why is the pound, question.The poundm questionI HAVE a soft spot for St Thomasrsquo Hospital in London, so much so that we named our son after it. I expect Boris Johnson does too ndash a massively grateful marshmallow spot, right next to his repaired lungs, now that he is out of intensive care. When he recovers, and when this transition period on leaving the EU is over, hersquoll be forced to put ndashnot pound million a week ndash a major investment into the NHS, bumping up the pay of not just nurses and doctors but the vital ancillary staff, like cleaners, who risked their lives to save his.Perhaps even build those  news hospitals he promised, not just fitting out the insides of already existing buildings. Perhaps hersquoll even suggest his partner, Carrie, has their baby at St Thomasrsquo, rather in some private hospital Irsquove met Boris two or three times, even suggested where he could park his bikeat the Commons when he was mayor of London, and he has always been affable,faintly dismissive, in the way that good-natured toffs treat their minions. So I wish his physical health well,not his political one.My boy had a dficult birth and he, too, was saved by the le-saving intervention of the staff. So we decided to put in Thomas as as middle name and as he was born just as Big Ben was striking midday just across the Thames we put that in too ndashno, not noon, Ben.It would have been my we Justinersquos birthday tomorrow had she lived. Not even St Thomasrsquo could have saved her. Missed by us all, every day.

title: coronavirus-easter-three-fantastic-treats-make-family
story: Well, not quite ... just because were in lockdown doesnt mean we have to do without the traditional chocolate treats.Andyou cant get out to the shop to buy some, why not stay at home and make your own  Weve teamed up with The Stair Arms Hotel in Pathhead, Midlothian, to bring you recipes for three Easter treats that all the family will love making ... and eating!The Stair Arms Chocolate TrufflesThese homemade treats are the perfect alternative to shop bought chocolate eggs this Easter.Simple and delicious, this recipe uses mainly cupboard ingredients and is perfect for the whole family to help make and enjoy.Can store in the fridge ndashthey last that long hellipCooking time:  minutesServes: Around - Ingredients digestive biscuitsg butterg condensed milktbsp cocoa powderg desiccated coconut, plus extra for decoration Methodbull In a plastic bag crush the digestive biscuits using a rolling pin.bull Put the butter and the condensed milk into a pan and melt the butter over a low heat. Leave to cool slightly.bull Add the biscuits, cocoa and coconut to the butter and condensed milk and stir together. Make sure it is well stirred.bull Form the mixture into truffles about the size of a golf ball. Top tip ndash Dip your hands in a little water between truffles to avoid sticking.bull Roll the truffles in coconut .White Chocolate CheesecakeIf yoursquore planning an indulgent dessert for your Easter lunch then look no further than The Stair Armsrsquo to-die-for white chocolate cheesecake.Preparation time: around  hoursIngredients:g digestive biscuitsg unsalted and melted butter with extra to greaseg broken-up white chocolateg full-fat cream cheeseg mascarponeml double creamg berries to serve Method:bull Bash the biscuits in a plastic bag with a rolling pin.bull Grease and line a cm deep cake tin. Add the crushed biscuits to the tin and pat until flat. Leave to set for  minutes.bull Start to melt the chocolate over a small amount of hot water in a heat-proof bowl. Stir occasionally. Remove the bowl from the heat and leave to cool for about  minutes.bull Meanwhile, whisk the cream cheese and mascarpone together. Add the double cream and continue to whisk until the mixture can keep its shape. Add the melted chocolate and whisk until fully combined.bull Spoon the mixture over the cool and set biscuit base and leave in the fridge to set for around  hours.bull Decorate with either berries or crushed up mini eggs to make it the perfect Easter centrepiece.Nutella CheesecakeThis is the ultimate indulgence! A combination of creamy Nutella and crunchy hazelnuts makes this dessert a winner with the whole family.Preparation time: around  hoursIngredientsg digestive biscuitsg soft unsalted butterg Nutella g chopped toasted hazelnutsg cream cheese g icing sugar Methodbull Put the digestives into a bowl of a processor, add the butter and a tablespoon of the Nutella and blitz until it clumps together. Add  tablespoons of the toasted hazelnuts and continue to blitz until a damp and sandy mixture is formed.bull Tip the mixture into a cm deep tin and press into the base. Leave in the fridge to cool.bull Whisk the cream cheese and icing sugar together until smooth and then add the remaining Nutella to the mix and continue to whisk.bull Take the cooled and set base from the fridge and carefully spoon the mixture on top, spreading evenly. Put the hazelnuts over the top and leave to cool for  hours or overnight.The Stair Arms Hotel at Pathhead, Midlothian, is a family-owned and managed hotel, promising a warm Scottish welcome.It is an original coaching inn, commissioned in  by Lord and Lady Stair of the Oxenfoord Estate. For the last  years it has been run by the Ramsay family.The hotel is an ideal stopover on the main Edinburgh-to-Borders route. Here you can be assured that you will receive warm hospitality while enjoying a relaxed atmosphere. You can enjoy a good nightrsquos sleep in our beautully decorated rooms and a hearty Scottish breakfast before carrying on with your journey.The comfortable and cosy restaurant, complete with a roaring log fire, provides an excellent setting for you to enjoy freshly-cooked homemade food. The Ramsay family have built up a reputation for providing a high standard of food using local produce.Similarly, the Coffee House area is lovely, relaxing and comfortable serving Illy coffee and a great range of home baking.

title: perfect-collection-inside-mind---cellar---greatest-ever-whisky-fan
story: The very well-off boss of a soft drinks bottling giant, Richard Leonard Gooding could afford to live in a certain style.His sprawling French-style chateau mansion in an upscale quarter of Coloradorsquos Arapahoe County featured a wide, sweeping drive, beautully landscaped lawns, crystal-clear lakes and an ornamental maze.In his jet-lagged state, those alone were enough to make a weary visitorrsquos head spin. But as whisky expert Angus MacRaild was about to find, behind the doors of the impressive property lurked an intoxicating and quite unexpected treasure trove unlike anything he had ever seen before.ldquoI was in the middle of Colorado, several thousand feet above sea level and feeling rather spaced out from jet lag, he recalls.ldquoI was quite discombobulated anyway. But inside this grand house and down the stairs in the basement was a wooden led room ndash a whisky cellar.As he crossed the tartan carpet, his jaw dropped. ldquoThe wooden shelves stretched from the carpet to rafters, specially designed for this whisky collection, he recalls.ldquoNo-one knew about this. It was like a preserved Aladdinrsquos Cave of treasures. It was remarkable.Whisky expert MacRaild had been dispatched to the high plains of Colorado to check out a collection of malt whiskies gathered by a very private enthusiast.What he found was a real-le whisky galore.On each shelf was crammed bottle after bottle of single malt whisky rarities. A  Macallan Fine and Rare -year-old worth an eye-watering pound million, bottle after bottle of  Black Bowmore ndash each one estimated at pound, ndash a Glenfiddich  Rare Collection , one of just  bottles ever produced, and dozens of highly sought-after bottles from lost distilleries: Dallas Dhu, Glenugie, Killyloch, some almost a century old.Still reeling from encountering one of the worldrsquos most stunning and secret collections of single malt whisky, MacRaild spotted something  that would make his heart sing.ldquoAt the back was a typical pub wood bar with a gantry and a wee sink. It was jammed full of bottles.ldquoIt was ridiculous, he laughs. ldquoThere would be a fairly standard bottle of whisky that would cost maybe  or  sitting next to a bottle that was worth ,.ldquoThat was his drinking stock, stuffed behind the bar, ready to be drunk.ldquoThat told me this collector was first and foremost a drinker who loved the social aspect of Scotch whisky.It seemed Gooding ndash who had been raised surrounded by soft drinks bottles so could be forgiven for enjoying the clink of a glass bottle against a tumbler ndash wasnrsquot collecting because he wanted to make a buck. Rather, this was a man who quite simply adored a decent dram.In the coming week, Perthshire-based Whisky Auctioneer will carry out the second part of its sale of Richard Goodingrsquos single malt whiskies ndash named ldquoThe Perfect Collection.The first, in February, saw more than , malts from the collection attract , bidders from  countries. Highlights included a rare Macallan  Valerio Adami -year-old which alone sold for a record-breaking pound,.It raised more than pound million.The second instalment of the collection consisting of almost , bottles went on sale on Friday and will continue for a further eight days. It is expected to achieve a similar sum.Part of the collectionrsquos charm, says MacRaild, is it eccentricity, quality and the fact that no-one knew it was there.ldquoIt was collected before whisky collecting took off as a global phenomenon," he says. "It was an age of innocence when collecting whisky was a niche thing.ldquoThe internet came and changed the face of what was just a hobby.Born in Denverrsquos wealthy Belcaro neighbourhood in , Richard Goodings financial clout to lavish cash on fine whisky was never a problem.His grandfather, James A Gooding, launched the Pepsi Cola Bottling Company of Denver in , supplying bottles of soft drink across Colorado and parts of surrounding states.After his father retired, Gooding took over as owner and chief executive officer. However, his tenure only lasted from  to  when, aged , he decided to sell the company back to the parent corporation.The move brought him a fortune ndash his wealth was rumoured to be in the region of  million.And what better way to celebrate than with a dram or two However, nipping to his local Walmart was not going to bring Richard Gooding the liquid treasures he sought.His personal pilot, a silver-haired chap called Kirk with a bushy white moustache, recalls frequent jaunts across the Atlantic with Gooding in search of single malt whiskies.Speaking in a video produced for the Perthshire company organising the sale of Goodingrsquos collection, Whisky Auctioneers, he offers a fascinating insight into the lestyle that money can bring.ldquoWe went to Ireland, Scotland,  or  trips specically for auctions for purchasing whisky, he says.ldquoWe pulled up to Talisker and just knocked on the door. People answered and they gave us tours. It was before all the tasting rooms were open and all the displays and stuff like that.ldquoHe would go to Macallan and start taking to the people, saying lsquoOkay, I would like to have this one and this and that one and that onersquo.ldquoAnd they are looking at him and saying, lsquoDo you want this, or this rsquo And he would say lsquoI want them all!rsquo.ldquoHe was into the whisky business long before it became as popular as it is today, he adds.ldquoHe tasted a lot of them when we were on these trips, but the majority of his purpose was to have a collection of one of everything that was ever made.ldquoThe lsquoperfect collectionrsquo.Gooding, with a self-taught knowledge of whisky and very deep pockets, enjoyed a warm welcome at distilleries which were still to witness the global explosion in whisky collecting that exists today.ldquoIt was a golden age when you could find an incredible array of bottles, adds MacRaild.ldquoApparently he just turned up and bought stuff. He would go around Speyside with his driver and stop off at distilleries to see what was interesting.ldquoHe would go to Gordon  MacPhail, the whisky specialist shop in Elgin which had incredible stocks, and fill his boots.Gooding bought at the perfect time ndash many of the bottles he acquired  years ago for a few hundred pounds are now worth several thousands.ldquoRichardrsquos mission was to collect a bottle that represented every single distillery, said his we Nancy, who he had met at high school in Denver.Perhaps she was too busy enjoying her collection of horses to pay much attention to her husbandrsquos wood-led cellar, groaning with bottles and where he would happily consume parts of his collection at the bar.ldquoHe opened a lot of bottles with his friends, says MacRaild, who has helped to catalogue the collection for the auction sale.ldquoYou would find a fairly standard bottle of whisky that would have cost maybe  or  sitting next to a bottle that was worth ,.Yet, perhaps strangely for a man who built one of the worldrsquos most impressive whisky collections, his lersquos passion is absent from the obituary in the Denver Post following his death at the age of  after an -year struggle with melanoma.Described as a ldquoquiet and generous philanthropist who did not enjoy the limelight, among his interests ndash aviation, boat design, architecture, music, language, food and travel ndash whisky does not get a mention.ldquoHe was a person who enjoyed the concept of design, his obituary adds, perhaps an explanation for those remarkable wooden shelves, heaving with bottles of ious shapes, some with artistically designed labels, others strikingly plain, such as the most expensive of the current lot, that  Macallan Fine and Rare -year-old And like that perfectly arranged collection, he took pride in presentation: he didnrsquot do ldquodressing down, preferring a well-cut suit worn with a carefully-chosen shirt ndash he would always wear pink on a Wednesday as a tribute to all fighting breast cancer.His colourful collections of shirts were matched by one of his ldquosignature Leonard Paris silk ties.ldquoHis collection of ties has to be record-setting for quantity and iety, his obituary adds.Of course, ties are not what Richard Gooding is now known for.Experts who have sted through his whisky collection have described it as one of the most exciting discoveries of the whisky world. Itrsquos ldquojaw-dropping, ldquonothing short of overwhelming, ldquoeclectic and ldquopeerless, they say.Yet MacRaild says Richard Gooding was probably no dferent to the rest of us.He simply loved a dram.ldquoOnce you are bitten by the Scotch bug, thatrsquos it for le. Itrsquos a lelong passion. Itrsquos social, you can always learn more, therersquos always something to discover and at the end of the day itrsquos a delicious drink, he says.ldquoFor a pleasurable evening with pals, itrsquos intellectual nourishment, great flavour, history and geography, all those stories attached.ldquoRichard Gooding loved the liquid.ldquoHe bought whisky for his own pleasure ndash and he enjoyed it.Auction highlights - three bottles and what the catalogue says about themBowmore  Largiemeanoch  Year OldIslayrsquos oldest working distillery, Bowmore was established in  and is now regarded as one of the most popular malts not only on Islay, but in the whole of Scotland. The distillery was acquired by Stanley P Morrison in , ushering in an era of iconic single malts, including the legendary Black Bowmore, credited by many as the genesis of whisky collecting, bottled in . The distillery was bought under the control Suntory the year before , and it remains one of the most collectible brands in Scotch whisky today.This is an incredibly rare example, bottled under the Largiemeanoch label, a brand devised for a series of private bottlings for The Howgate Wine Co in Edinburgh in the late s.A legendary bottle of whisky, distilled at Bowmore in  and bottled from a vatting of three sherry casks. A -year-old was also bottled.Glenlivet Liqueur Scotch Mayor, Sworder and Co circa sThis was bottled by Mayor, Sworder  Co, a fine wine merchant from London. Up until the mid-s, the company also had many dealings in spirits, bottling whisky and gin. The firm contracted blends from Bulloch Lade, but also produced its own label called Red Monogram.It regularly received fillings of Glenlivet and Ardbeg for its production, and in earlier years, sought-after Longmorn malt as well. These casks would occasionally be bottled as single malts for the companys more discerning customers, as was the case here. Its Glenlivet was often pre-vatted for blending purposes, so bottled as a single malt here with an undiscernible vintage or age statement. This was bottled at some point in the early s.The early reverence for this now iconic Speyside distillery is clear in the wax dipping of these bottle tops, a practice the firm usually reserved for its high-end vintage port.Glenfiddich  Peter J RussellGlenfiddich was an early advocate of the single malt Scotch category, and its faith is rewarded today by being one of the best-selling Scotch brands in the world. It became the first distillery to market its single malt brand in , and was the first to open its facility to visitors. Glenfiddich was an important trailblazer in the whisky industry, whose contribution cannot be forgotten. The scale of its operation today is a testament to this.This is a spectacular example of one of the distillerys early single malts, bottled here especially for Peter J Russell  Co in Edinburgh.Pre-war vintages in single malt are exceptionally rare, particularly from distilleries like Glenfiddich. This is a real opportunity to own a true piece of whisky history.Longrow  First Distillation - Last CaskFirst distilled in , Longrow is the peated single malt produced at Springbank distillery. Although very popular, Longrow remains an elusive whisky, with only - casks of it filled at the distillery each year. Early champions of this spirit included the legendary Italian bottler, Silvano Samaroli, who bought and bottled a number of famous casks from the inaugural vintage, and is credited by many with a good deal of the brands success. It remains revered by connoisseurs to this day. ######This special release was bottled from cask #, the last to be filled during the inaugural year of production in .

title: coronavirus-scotland-ron-mckays-alternative-easter
story: Itrsquos Easter Sunday and the usual rituals are mothballed. No gathering with friends, distant family and neighbours for a drink or a meal. Egg rolling is confined to your garden,you have one, andnot down the stairs in the close, although it will have to be remotely planned with your neighbours, to avoid cross-contamination ndash who wants colliding eggs and the collateral damage that could cause, never mind the potentially-hazardous spray of droplets and expletives  The soundtrack should be Roll Away The Stone by Mott The Hoople.Some doolally people believe the G network is carrying the virus, so itrsquos altogether more likely ndash although not at all likely ndash that egg splatters could do it. Well, the thing is thought to have started in a livestock market, not on a piece of tiny hardware  metres above Earth. So rather than setting fire to masts, disinfecting wally closes would be more efficacious.Today is, of course, the religious high point of the year, although you wonrsquot be able to go to church unless yoursquore living in a Bible Belt state, which Irsquom sure yoursquore not, or in Ohio where a woman leaving a packed church told CNN shersquod be okay because she was ldquocovered in Jesusrsquo blood, while not showing any outward signs. And they let these people out in public to mingle!If you are not in Ohio, there are all sorts of virtual services taking place,you need religious sustenance, from churches and abbeys throughout the world, from the plain and unadorned to the celebrity.Chanter Andrea Bocelli is streaming a live performance on his YouTube channel tonight at pm from the epicentre of the virus, Milan and its empty Duomo. And the seriously wacky Kanye West and uumlber-a Mariah Carey are taking part in one from a mega-church in Houston, although I hate to think what theyrsquore going to duet ndash Ave Mariah  ndash and what itrsquos going to sound like.Easter is celebrated in all sorts of dferent ways, in normal times and abnormal ways, throughout the world. Here are some alternative suggestions for our pandemic age.:In the Czech Republic and Slovakia, men and boys roam the streets with ribboned willow switches looking for girls to whip, which is, surprisingly enough, not a jailable offence, but is meant to hasten good health and beauty. Thatrsquos out, of course, with lockdown, which is pleasing to about half of the population.In the Philippines, devout Catholics practice self-crucixion and flagellation, which can, of course, be done at home with a dogrsquos lead or aof barbed wire, but tends to play havoc with the soft furnishings.Instead, the scourging should be done with wall-to-wall episodes of Mrs Brown complete with subtitles, which wonrsquot make any more sense than the spoken word.The Easter Bunny eschews visiting New Zealand, and who can blame itbecause in Otago, while wersquore rolling our eggs, they grab their guns and go on The Great Easter Bunny Hunt, with a top prize for the most flopsies killed. More than , get it each Easter, which hardly seems spiritual.These bloodthirsty Kiwis clearly like a spot of adventure. They need to form a WhatsApp group and climb Everest virtually, although unfortunately there wonrsquot be any avalanches or plunges from great heights, unless itrsquos down a set of stairs.The challenge is to climb the mountain quickestby repeatedly climbing stairs inside or outside asascending the worldrsquos highest peak. Itrsquos about , steps, equivalent to the , metres.For the older or more sedentary itrsquos to get to Everest base camp, some , steps, and set up your own survival tent from several sheets, cardboard boxes, clothes racks or chairs. The heating has to be turned off and the windows opened, just to simulate the real experience.Believe it or not, people are actually doing this in Britain.In Hungary, young men pour buckets of water over young women to aid fertility, although you might have thought it would dampen the urge. This can still be done it you live in a high flat but itrsquos not likely to bolster community spirit.Why not just mix washing-up liquid in a bowl with water and make bubble wands from wire or coat hangers ndash you can even loop your thumb and first finger to make one, although itrsquos a touch messy ndash and blow them out the window. Although itrsquos a lot quicker and more fun with the bucket of water.In Greece, they paint eggs completely red, symbolising that Christ blood again, but also the stuff under the skin which keeps us alive. This presents two linked problems.First off you probably canrsquot get any eggs in the supermarket, because the shelves have been pillaged, and certainly not the free range ones because all the eco-conscious hoarders have nabbed them. Then therersquos the paint problem.With many DIY emporia closed for the duration, where are you going to get the paint  Perhaps therersquos lipstick lying around of vaguely the right shade  Crayons  You could let a vein, but that seems a little extreme, and you canrsquot invite a self-flagellator round, what with the distancing. Try ketchup or dip them in a tin of tomatoes.In Haux, France, they have an even more eggs-centric ritual, where they crack , of them into a huge frying pan in the square and make a massive omelette, probably mixing it with a shovel, to share among the villagers. This clearly canrsquot be done today, for all of the reasons already stated. If you are community-spirited you could donate to a foodbank, or lob a goodie at a neighbour out for the permitted walk or,you dont like them, a brick.In Corfu, they gather at their windows at am and when the church bell sounds hurl water-filled crockery and jugs into the street, the symbolism of which is to create an earthquake like the one which is supposed to have occurred with Christrsquos resurrection, or alternatively may just be a way of letting off steam.I suspect itrsquos probably sponsored by a pottery company or a household goods shop. This, however, is a practice to be encouraged, particularly appropriate when yoursquove got a nuisance neighbour. You can always replace with plastic or,saving the planet, paper.For Norwegians ndash who cleave the darkness and donrsquot have much choice for much of the year ndash itrsquos criminal intent time. TV channels run wall-to-wall crime shows and publishers commission new detective tales and whodunnits to come out for this weekend.Across the country people escape to mountain cabins and plough through the grisly tomes.Itrsquos a great idea which was apparently kicked off by a  novel called Bergen Train Looted In The Night .We obviously canrsquot travel to our country retreats, unlike the former Chief Medical Officer, but we can grab a bundle of thrillers and retreat to the garden hut, or that Everest base camp on the landing, disturbed only by the far-off sounds of Kanye and Mariah or earthenware shattering on concrete.

title: coronavirus-scotland-climbers-turn-inventive-ways-scaling-countrys-mountains-lockdown
story: Although for some climbing enthusiasts there really is no stopping them and they have come up their own inventive ways to scale new heights.Mr Smith, from Edinburgh, said: ldquoIt can be climbed in any form ndash stairs, garden etc. If out of onersquos own home it may need to be climbed in stages during daily exercise outings and in accordance with rules. My own garden has a five-metre rise requiring  laps to reach the summit.ldquoIt does seem a good way to keep fit and virtually in touch with our beloved Scottish mountains. If you think merit in this perhaps it could be promoted to other members.Read more: Coronavirus in Scotland: Thousands of student nurses and graduating doctor take up posts early to support those involved in the fight on the front lineFellow climber Alan Mackay hasnrsquot been slow on ideas either. During his time in lockdown he has managed to climb the equivalent of Schiehallionand Ben Nevis .Mr Mackay, from Bonnybridge, near Falkirk, said: ldquoI am working from home at the moment as part of my role with the Duke of Edinburgh Award Scheme. We have been trying to keep the young people going and motivated online. I also do volunteer work with Black Dog Outdoors, a charity supports people with mental health issues. With this lockdown period I was up for a challenge as well and I know how important it is to keep active.It wasnrsquot long before Mr Mackay realised the answer was right there in his home.He added: ldquoI realisedI canrsquot get outdoors the stairs was the next best thing. I am off on a Wednesday so I have made that my day to set myself a challenge. I have already climbed the equivalent of the Schiehallion and Ben Nevis.ldquoI worked out how many flights of stairs I would need to climb for each one. It was roughly six steps a metre. Schiehallion worked out at  flights of stairs while Ben Nevis was  flights of stairs. Irsquom already planning on doing Ben Lomond this Wednesday. I approach as I would any climb. I take water when required to stay hydrated, have a break, but it is great to be climbing Ben Nevis in my slippers on the stairs.Read more: Coronavirus in Scotland: Nursing chief in plea for better equipmentJust days before movement restrictions were imposed, there was images of people flocking to remote areas while supposed to be maintaining social distancing.But Mountaineering Scotland were keeping people updated with advice and adapted as days went on. Now they are trying to ensure that people are fit and in shape to head back to the hills when restrictions ease.Through their development arm ClimbScotland, which is a programme by Mountaineering Scotland to help inspire people of all ages and abilities to get involved in climbing, both indoors and outdoors, they have been trying to keep enthusiasts engaged during lockdownWith members of Mountaineering Scotland and Climb Scotland craving ways of keeping fit in preparation for ing to climbing when lockdown ends, Jamie Smith, development manager for ClimbScotland, said they started to look at ways they could offer advice and came up with the idea of #Quarantraining. A number people have been posting their own activities on the Facebook page showing the kinds of activities they have been doing.He added: ldquoPeople were wanting to know what they could do and that is when we came up with the idea of quarantraining. We have a programme which involves a daily word and people can do exercises linked to each letter of a word we post on social media. We have YouTube videos which show how you can keep fit while doing everyday tasks such as making a cup of tea.Already Climb Scotland is thinking ahead to the days after lockdown.Mr Smith added: ldquoWe are having conversations about that at the moment and I think there will be need to be a phased approach. Anyto climbing or hillwalking will have to be done gradually and safely. If you have had a month or two off from climbing, you are not going to be as fit and have the same strength back immediately. Finger strength is very important for a climber and that can be one of the first injuries when people make a comeback as it needs to be done gradually.ldquoWe have to make sure that peopleto the sport safely. If you have had a break from any sport you need to ease back into it and mountaineering is no dferent.ldquoGiven that people have been in lockdown, it many well spark interest from newcomers to the activity as I am sure people will want to get outdoors and enjoy Scotlandrsquos beauty.* Shops across Scotland are closing. story: Here, Jamie Smith, development manager for ClimbScotland, shares some key advice which people can follow during lockdownHabitsThe first thing I want to talk to you about is habits. We all have habits that we perform every single day, we make cups of tea, we brush our teeth, we have a glass of water. What I want to show you is a way we can take advantage of these current habits, to make new habits. So, letrsquos take my example of drinking tea.While Irsquom waiting for my tea to brew, I can practice doing push ups. Over time doing push-ups will become a new habit attached on to my old habit of making tea.PracticeThe next point is, I would like you to think of these exercises as practice not training. In training itrsquos easy to get bogged down by sets and reps but these are not important for practice. In practice, we arenrsquot concentrating on how many reps we can do but rather on the movement itself.Practice is as much about increasing our own body awareness as it is about performing the exercise. Try and do these exercises slowly and with focus. Ask yourself questions like, where am I generating tension in my body now If yoursquore struggling to focus as the exercise is too easy or too hard, each video will show you some iations that you may find easier or harder.FormThe last point I want to talk about is Form.No-onersquos form is perfect when theyrsquore starting out with a new exercise. We all find it dficult doing something new, so donrsquot beat yourself up about it and more importantly donrsquot give up in frustration.Dficulty gives an opportunity to improve.In each of the videorsquos wersquoll give you some pointers to help improve your form.
